Award.AwardTitle: Mechanisms of RNA polymerase-specific transcription complex assembly on U1 and U6 snRNA gene promoters

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit: The small nuclear RNAs (snRNAs) known as U1, U2, U4, U5, and U6 comprise a highly abundant class of RNA molecules that are required for pre-messenger RNA splicing in higher organisms. These snRNAs are synthesized by RNA polymerase II with the exception of U6, which is synthesized by RNA polymerase III. Despite this difference in RNA polymerase specificity, U6 genes and the RNA polymerase II-transcribed snRNA genes utilize similar regulatory signals and overlapping sets of transcription factors for their expression. The main goal of the project is to gain an understanding of the structure-function relationships that are involved in recruiting the correct RNA polymerase to initiate synthesis of the correct snRNAs. Transcription of both classes of snRNA genes requires a unique protein factor referred to as the snRNA-activating protein complex (SNAPc). This factor recognizes an essential promoter element termed the PSE located in the DNA 40-75 base pairs (bp) upstream of the start site of RNA synthesis. In the fruit fly D. melanogaster (the model organism used in this project), DmSNAPc is composed of three subunits that together carry out sequence-specific recognition of the ~21 bp long PSEA (the fruit fly PSE). Even though a U1 PSEA and a U6 PSEA differ at only 5 of 21 nucleotide positions, this sequence difference plays a major role in determining the RNA polymerase specificity of fly snRNA genes. Furthermore, the three subunits of assume a different conformation when bound to a U6 versus a U1 PSEA. This conformational difference is believed to be responsible for the recruitment of the correct RNA polymerase. To better understand the conformational differences of DmSNAPc bound to U1 and U6 PSEAs, a novel technique developed in the PI's lab will be employed that uses site-specific protein-DNA cross-linking combined with chemical cleavage of the protein at defined sites. Contact points made between the largest DmSNAPc subunit and U6 promoter DNA will be compared with the contact points made between this subunit and U1 promoter DNA. Next, pre-initiation complex (PIC) assembly on U1 and U6 promoters will be investigated, with primary emphasis on RNA polymerase II recruitment to the TATA-less U1 promoter, but analogous experiments will be performed to investigate Pol III PIC assembly on the U6 promoter. Finally, the overall contour shape of DmSNAPc bound to the U1 and U6 PSEAs will be studied by cryo-electron microscopy, and X-ray crystallography will be employed to investigate the structure of DmSNAPc and it subunits at the atomic level. The results of the research will contribute widely to the scientific community's understanding of gene expression at the level of RNA synthesis. Fruit fly U1 genes serve as a particularly tractable paradigm for investigating RNA polymerase II transcription complex assembly on TATA-less promoters, a process that is currently very poorly understood. More generally, this system serves as an excellent model for understanding how very subtle changes in macromolecular interactions and assembly can lead to significantly different biological outcomes.

Broader Impacts: The research will be performed by students in satisfaction of their B.S., M.S., and Ph.D. degrees in biochemistry/molecular biology. The project will provide training for their future careers in the biotechnology industry, for advancement to graduate and professional schools, or to careers in academia as well as teaching at the community college level. San Diego State University, due to its border location and emphasis on undergraduate as well as graduate instruction, serves a large body of undergraduate students from underrepresented ethnic groups. The PI is active in undergraduate classroom teaching and has a strong track record and history of involving underrepresented students in research, from high school through the graduate level.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit:

In higher organisms the correct expression of genetic information present in the DNA is crucial for the normal development of an embryo into an adult member of the species. In humans and other multi-cellular organisms, most genes are split into segments called "exons" that contain the coding information for a specific protein. The exons are separated from each other by "introns" that are not directly involved in coding for protein. During the process of "messenger RNA splicing", the introns are removed from the messenger RNA precursor in order to generate a functional messenger RNA that can correctly code for the proper protein product. The process of messenger RNA splicing requires the presence and activity of five essential small nuclear RNAs (snRNAs). In this project, the Stumph research lab studied the biosynthesis of these snRNAs that are absolutely required for the health and well-being of all higher organisms.

The model organism chosen for studying snRNA biosynthesis (or transcription) is the widely-used fruit fly Drosophila melanogaster. This system was chosen because the biochemical in vitro systems are more robust in the fruit fly than those available in human or other vertebrate systems for studying the transcription of the largest class of snRNA genes. Most of what is learned in this model system is expected to be directly translatable to the human system, although important evolutionary differences may also be revealed.

All higher organisms possess three different RNA polymerases. Each RNA polymerase synthesizes RNA from a different and distinct set of genes, and it is important that every gene be transcribed by the correct RNA polymerase. Interestingly, some of the snRNAs (for example, U1 snRNA) are transcribed by RNA polymerase II, but others (for example, U6 snRNA) are transcribed by RNA polymerase III. The work in this project is designed to uncover the molecular mechanisms that determine and specify which RNA polymerase is recruited to a particular snRNA gene.

A puzzling aspect of this question is that U1 and U6 snRNA genes have very similar regulatory sequences ("promoter sequences") in their DNA to which the same protein complex, the small nuclear RNA activating protein complex (SNAPc), binds. Although these promoter sequences are similar, they differ at certain important base pairs in the DNA that govern RNA polymerase specificity. These slight differences in DNA sequence are proposed to affect the shape or conformation of SNAPc, and, as a result, different surfaces of SNAPc are believed to be exposed on U1 and U6 snRNA gene promoters that subsequently leads to the recruitment of the different RNA polymerases. The project aims to test this hypothesis by gaining an understanding of exactly how the process works at the molecular level.

This NSF-funded project has provided significant new insight into the structure of SNAPc and has provided additional evidence that SNAPc indeed interacts differently with U1 and U6 snRNA gene promoters. Drosophila SNAPc is composed of three separate protein subunits, and the work in this project determined for the first time how the largest member of these three subunits is arranged on the snRNA gene promoters. Furthermore, specific differences were identified between how this largest SNAPc subunit interacts with U1 and U6 promoters. Finally, by beginning studies on protein assemblies known as the "general transcription machinery", the project has begun to reveal how SNAPc is able to recruit different RNA polymerases to different classes of snRNA genes.

The NSF-supported work has been communicated to the scientific community in four refereed articles in highly respected journals and by numerous conference presentations. These results and additional follow-up studies currently in progress are revealing significant information regarding a unique and unusual method utilized to regulate gene expression. This research has provided knowledge that addresses how decisions can be made at the cellular and molecular level to select between two alternative and distinct biological pathways.

 

Broader Impacts.

This project funded the education and training of four Ph.D. students, four M.S. students, one M.A. student, seven undergraduate students, and one high school student at San Diego State University. Almost all of these students are either continuing their training in the field of biochemistry/molecular biology at the graduate or professional school level, or they are working as scientists in the biotechnology industry. Of these seventeen students, twelve were female, and six were either Hispanic or members of other underrepresented groups. Thus, by contributing to the educational and training aspects of a younger and more diverse generation, this project will continue to contribute to the scientific workforce of the nation for years into the future.
